column1: When it was found that the Griffin showed no sign of going away
column2: all the people who were able to do so left the town. The canons and the higher officers of the church had fled away during the first day of the Griffin's visit
column3: leaving behind only the Minor Canon and some of the men who opened the doors and swept the church. All the citizens who could afford it shut up their houses and traveled to distant parts
column4: and only the working people and the poor were left behind. After some days these ventured to go about and attend to their business
column5: for if they did not work they would starve. They were getting a little used to seeing the Griffin; and having been told that he did not eat between equinoxes
column6: they did not feel so much afraid of him as before.Day by day the Griffin became more and more attached to the Minor Canon. He kept near him a great part of the time
column7: and often spent the night in front of the little house where the young clergyman lived alone.
